text: Bottle from VE. Nose stale and slightly nutty coffee. Pour deep, dark, sludgy brown right from the start, so obvious motor oil in the glass, head is tight, dark brown. Body only medium in fullness, sludgy-smooth and thick; medium sweet with bursting sweet fruit (raisin, plum, cherry, berry) mixed with sugar; strong but very smooth and well-integrated alcohol with no rough patches; coffee is milder and one of the complementary shades. Not much roast or scorch, but there is nice chocolate, if at a low level, with subtle spikes of molasses but no cocoa. Hint of cream but no vanilla or bitterness.  Gooey but not milky, nicely beany, and has the feeling of something quite concentrated thats to be diluted later with water - truly spoonable. A big winner on secondary characteristics, but boy are those enough to carry it! [2017.06.21: 3.7]
Old note - draft from Crest in Clintonville: dark brown, medium tan head. aroma of coffee, earthy. tastes are chocolate, light even coffee, sweet and roasty malts.
bottle - stout shared. very delicious stout. excellent coffee and chocolate notes. quite good

Pours black with a tiny kahki head. Aroma of coffee and more coffee. Tase the same with a little creaminess. Slightly sweet. Light carbonation. Very nice coffee cream stout. Little lacing in the glass. Very tasty kf you like coffee stouts.
Smokey smell mixed with coffee and rum. Creamy black color. Tastes like coffee and a rum finish. Delicious!
Bottle from Flanigans. Roasted aroma with notes of coffee, vanilla and oak. Pretty basic. Deliciously smooth stout with some heat, really nice coffee and sweet malts. Wow. Almost Storm King esque.
Thick aroma of coffee and cream. Medium mouthfeel that coats your tongue. Coffee taste nicely balanced by the lactose. Toasty malts. Very well done. Bottle.

bottle @ Chief Market / Lima OH --- Aroma of roasted malt and mocha. Opaque brown/black color, brown head that sticks at 1", sheets of lace. Taste is creamy roasted malt that moves through suitably light carbonation to solid bittersweet mocha. Full-bodied, perfectly balanced, complex, and light in the belly. Highly recommended.

Bottle. Espresso bean, dark chocolate malt, and dry grass aroma. Black with moderate brown head. Moderately sweet latte, dark chocolate, and moderately bitter coffee bean/hay flavor. Nice body. Very tasty.

12 ounce bottle, stamp on the label says 10/31/16. Im assuming thats the bottled on date since Shorts website says this brew was a November 2016 release. Served in a pint glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with about an inch tan head that stuck around a while. Theres also a good amount of lacing. The brew smells like coffee, cream, roasted malt and some chocolate. I think the taste pretty much follows the aroma, its all coffee, cream, roasted malt and bittersweet chocolate. I think its more bitter than sweet, and thats fine with me! Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit creamy and coating with a good amount of carbonation. I liked this coffee stout, Ill see if I can find a 6-pack of this one to buy. $2.79 a single bottle.
Dark black. Khaki head. Creamy espresso. Slightly acidic from all of the espresso. Cocoa powder aftertaste. Delicious. Thx arminjewell!

Big rich coffee aroma, pours an opaque black with a quickly fading tan head. Very dark rich coffee notes coming through, with some sweetness tempering the roast in the finish. Theres a nice slick and full mouthfeel. This is a very good coffee stout.
Rich velvety black appearance. Creamy tan head. Very thick feel on the tongue. Coffee malty aroma. Coffee taste left on the tongue.

12oz bottle from the Malt Shoppe in Tosa. Very dark brown pour with a brown head leaving little lacing. Aroma has big coffee up front, with chocolate and other sweet malts. Taste is a well blended bitter coffee, sweet milk, and bittersweet chocolate. Not too thick. Medium bodied with some alcohol presence. The blend is quite good and the carbonation is soft. Finishes to the sweet side of bittersweet, although the bitterness is certainly in the battle. Quite sweet creamy, with a nice choco/coffee combo. Very solid and tasty. 14.4

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a small foamy brown head that left minimal lacing. The aroma was vanilla cream, coffee, lactose and hints of chocolate and rum. The flavor was bitter and toasty with notes of rum, red wine, coffee, vanilla and cream. Long finish. Moderately full bodied. Well done.

Bottle:
Pours oily and black with a dark tan head.
Chocolate, espresso, dark roast coffee aroma.
Flavour is creamy dark chocolate malt, smoky coffee malt.
Tons of roast.....
Chewy and rich.....Excellent.

12oz bottle. Dark brown with a generous mocha head that eventually fades to a thin layer. A very nice coffee and light lactose aroma with roasted malts, some bittersweet chocolate, hints of walnut. Moderate body and carbonation, smooth and easy to drink, a bit of booze and more lactose develops on the palate as things dry out, more coffee on the finish as well - yummy.

Pours black with a tan head. Big nose of espresso, cocoa and Sugar. Flavor is much the same. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Finish is bitter but not as much as you would think in this style. A little sticky on the lips. The coffee is center stage here. If your not into coffee stouts, this is probably not for you. I personally think this is really good.

Undated bottle, drunk 11/28/15. Opaque, no head, black. Heavy coffee. Roast. Dark chocolate. Vanilla. But mostly dark, thick coffee. In the mouth the coffee is bitter, ashy, and slightly putrid. Syrupy, too sweet. Can we forget the Creme series ever happened....

12 oz. can shared by Willrunforbeer. Pitch black , no head. Oily viscosity as the stout is swirled around the glass. Aroma is old coffee bean, chocolate and sugar. 
The flavor is pretty good, coffee bean that leans more on a coffee drink from Starbucks. Carbonation level is more mild with the slick oily texture I saw as I swirled the glass. Tastes good.
Poured from bottle thanks Willrunforbeer and jason. Pours dark black with dark beige head. Aroma of stale coffee amd roasted malt. Taste is burnt coffe and malt.
Man, smells like stale espresso or coffee beans. Flavor is super acidic coffee that lingers in my mouth. Dark pour. No head. This sucks.

12oz, thanks WillRun. Dark, black, reddish hues. no head. Aroma is just straight up coffee. acidic, roasty, bright. Very thin mouthfeel. acidic roasty finish. middle is some chocolate, coffee bean, not really fantastic. I guess would be good as a breakfast beer i hat was something I was into.

12oz bottle, just arrived as an extra from umich03jm. Thanks, Jason! Pours deep dark brown witha dark beige head. Aroma is all dark coffee, coffee grounds. Strong coffee flavor. Some caramel and chocolate underneath. Slight vegetal. I wish this bottle had a date.

Large sample board of fairly dark brown liquid with Amber edges. Little to no head with what I had appeared, dissipates fairly quickly. Aromas of chocolate and caramels with loads of espresso beans... Sweeter than I wouldve expected but still really fantastic and easy drinking. Minimal alcohol notes are present, with more residual sugar then I wouldve planned. Still enjoyable however.
The best stout ever. Coffee, chocolate, heaven, this stout is rich and warming just like your favorite cup a Joe.

12 oz. bottle poured into a snifter. Pours a very dark brown with almost no head and no lacing. Not quite fully opaque. Light comes through on the edges, but not through the body of the liquid. Looks thin, really. Strong coffee flavor. Almost smells like an over-brewed, burnt roast. Another review mentioned Starbucks coffee, probably for this reason. Roasted malts come through, but its faint by comparison to the coffee. Similar flavor. The coffee isnt as pronounced as it is in the nose. Its still strong, but it tastes more like a stout than just a cup of coffee. A lot of lactose sweetness comes through in the back and diminishes any bitterness. Very thin. Fairly low carbonation, but its not too low. Its an appropriate level. The body is what lets it down. I want something a bit chewier to stand up to the coffee. It doesnt taste like an 8% beer though. I would expect something with such little body to be a lot boozier at 8%, but it isnt. Certainly tasty and pretty easy to drink, since its so thin. The lactose and intensity of the coffee are a turn-off, though.
Bottle thanks to mikem409. Nose is light coffee. Light sugar. Taste is roasted and smooth at the same time.

Received in a recent trade. Beige head, thick black pour, aroma of roasted coffee, jellybean, palate is a nice weight, well bodied, and very slightly acidic
Goes down smooth with a bit of vanilla aftertaste, mellow and enjoyed it

Bottle. Pours black with a thin dark tan head. Smells of coffee and roasted malt. Full body with a creamy texture and a bit of alcohol warmth. Sweet with undertones of coffee and bittersweet chocolate. Nice flavor of coffee without overpowering the beer. Great job Shorts!

2014 bottle. Pours dark brown, near black, with a 2 finger mocha head that slowly recedes to a nice cap over the beer. Aromas are loaded with fresh coffee grounds, cocoa powder, chocolate mousse, vanilla and lightly roasted almonds. Taste is packed with coffee, espresso, Irish creme and cocoa. Great counterbalance between the sweet creamy mouthfeel and the dry cocoa. Really compliments each other. Nice chocolate notes shine through this beer...never getting too chewy with the medium carbonation helping push the flavors. A nice moderate coffee bitterness spikes the finish as it lingers with some Herseys Kiss milk chocolate goodness. Shorts really raised the bar with this years version. Very well done and slightly under-rated beer!

Wonderful, wonderful, wonderful. Glorious dark poor with a perfect tan head. Aroma is coffee, straight coffee homey. Taste is more coffee, chocolate and tobacco. Palate is thick. One of my favorite stouts.

Bottle. Pours black with only the slightest head ringing the glass. Minimal carbonation here. Aroma is coffee and roasted malts. Taste is extremely well-balanced: Coffee, creamy, and malty. A coffee bitterness lingers. Delicious. I need more...

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2014 An excellent coffee beer from Shorts. Beautiful tan brown with a frothy mocha head. The nose is freshly brewed coffee. Body and mouthfeel satisfying without being overly thick or syrupy. Great breakfast time beer or one for when you are flagging during a session.
Its delicious. super rich. There is a depth to the coffee flavor, out actually tastes like I will find bits of grounds in the bottom. Creamy in texture but not flavor.
Awesome beer! Flavors of rich coffee, cream, dark cocoa, molasses, toasted malts and notes of dark fruits. Perfect creamy feel. Heavy, but appropriately so.

Bottle from a trade with CBOK. Thanks! Pours a muddy brown with a micha thin head. No lacing. Aroma is solid with cocoa, Nequick, vanilla, heavy cream, sugar lactose, and coffee. I was surprised that it didnt taste more coffee flavored but that was fine. The balance of the coffee, cocoa, dark chocolate, roasted malts, and vanilla cream were perfect. Also a slight caramel flavor as well. Texture is buttery, creamy, and slick. Medium to full body, soft carb. Finish is dark chocolate, coffee, and lactose. So damn good.
Pours a dark brown with a foamy tan head. Aroma is chocolate and coffee. Flavor is the same, with a sweetness at the start and a light bitterness in the finish. Amazing.

Bottle. Pours jet black with little head. Head fades pretty quickly. Aroma is medium roast coffee/espresso, molasses, some kind of earthy/tree bark combo. Taste is rich, deep coffee flavor with the milk sugar kick. Exactly like an adult coffee - heavy on the palate but suprisingly low ABV. A nice after dinner beer. Shorts continues to impress!

Tap: 32 oz mug of coffee stout. Dark, dark, dark as hell; frothy, latte-looking tan foam on top of this abyss. Insane coffee aroma... Smells like a morning cup of coffee with cream & sugar, perhaps a flavor shot of vanilla. Thick & creamy sweetness with a gentle roasted quality; hints of dry cocoa, charred wood, & toasted barley round out the back-end. Very enticing. Columbian coffee flavor profile, again, with definitive (but not excessive) amounts of lactose creaminess & sweetness, just like an amped up cup of Joe. Mild woodiness, hint of nuts, & notable vanilla, likely from the lactose addition. Sweet up front, but leaves your palate lingering with a final touch of roasted bitterness & dark coffee bean flavor. Your palate screams for more... Coffee & beer lovers rejoice, our juxtaposition has arrived. People bust wads over Founders Breakfast Stout (which is great, dont get me wrong), but in my opinion, THIS is the Michigan coffee stout that I crave year in & year out. Absolutely fantastic.

Bottle (thanks Pete!). Pours very dark with a thin tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is coffee, roast malt, toast, touch of vanilla. Smells like a cup of iced coffee with lots of milk and sugar. Tastes like it smells. Sweet coffee, roasted malt. Mouth feel is creamy, slick, syrupy. Love it, but couldnt drink more than one.

Mocha colored body sprouts fluffy tan head. Beads aplenty. Intense coffee aroma: dark and roasty, so much blackness. 

Tastes a bit watery. Weak mouthfeel overall. Lactose adds a pleasant taste of creaminess despite the thin body. Far better than I expected for a Shorts beer.

Poured from a 12oz bottle I got in a trade, thanks Devin. Aroma is huge coffee. Flavors are coffee, light chocolate and caramel. Pretty is what the label says a coffee stout. The coffee flavor is amazing, the mouth is a little light but overall this a great coffee stout.
bottle. Black with small head. Thick pour. Dry stout with rich roasted malt and a ton of coffee flavor.

12 oz bottle into glass. Minneapolis. 

Appearance: Super dark black. Completely opaque. Small tan head. 

Aroma: Strong roasted coffee, chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt, smells delicious. 

Taste: Mildy sweet upfront, not too much, with a pleasantly bitter finish. 

Palate: Medium, almost full body. Not as much body as I would have liked. relatively low carbonation. Rich coffee finish. 

Overall: A nice beer. Very good flavor and aroma. Would have like a little more body and depth. Still well worth drinking.

Bottle from a trade. Pour is black with a slowly disappearing tan head. Aroma is faint but includes roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate. Flavor is more defined with the coffee roast shining through, also includes semi-sweet chocolate, cream, and vanilla.

Strong stuff. Good roasted malts and coffee aroma. Very dark with a tan head that coated the glass. Milky and creamy with average weight. Smooth drinking. More of the same as this was like drinking straight black coffee with a hint of hops bittering the finish. Some dark chocolate notes as well. Not very sweet. This one had some power to it.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2014 Good not great.sweet mild coffee flavor. Only one bottle have to re rate after second bottle. Second bottle sells me.  Really good.finish is sweet and creamy.  Much much better.  3.9 from 3.6

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 12/2/2013. Pours dense pitch black color with a 1-2 finger dense dark brown head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of huge roasted coffee bean, dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, char, toast, cream, light vanilla, and roasted earthiness. Fantastic aromas with big coffee presence and great complexity of roasted malt/cream notes; with great strength. Taste of roasted coffee bean, dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, toast, light char, cream, light vanilla, and roasted earthiness. Light roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of coffee, dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, light char, toast, cream, and roasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Damn nice balance and complexity of coffee, roasted malt, and cream flavors; with zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a very creamy and moderately slick mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is an awesome coffee stout! All around great balance and complexity of coffee, roasted malt, and cream flavors; and very smooth to sip on. A highly enjoyable offering.

Cup A Joe pours jet black with a dark brown head that lasts a good while. The aroma is coffee and vanilla. The flavor is coffee, vanilla and chocolate. Overall this is a tasty beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle pours black with low head. Aroma is sweet roasted coffee, taste is similar with a smooth sweet finish

Pours very dark brown to black with a thinner mocha cap that settles to a ring and leaves some nice soapy lace. Nose involves, hmmm, coffee? Lots of roasty coffee, some dark chocolate, almost some smoke, some underlying leafy herbal stuff. Pretty sweet, quite bitter. Medium bodied, creamy, oily and slick, soft carb, with a smooth milky and toasty finish. A really nice coffee stout, so silky smooth yet coffee-laden from start to finish. Yum.
Big coffee all around. Nice coffee bean bitterness flavor. Good stuff and can definitely drink a few.

Bottle. Coffee, coffee, coffee and a little chocolate too. This is great stuff. Dark brown pour and heavy roasted coffee aroma. Flavor is heavy coffee with a hint of chocolate. Nice and creamy.-- rated with beerbasher

$5.50 a pint at Boat Works in St. Clair Shores, Michigan.

I found a new Shorts favorite.

Appearance: Pitch black. Little head on it that goes away pretty quickly. Nice lacing at the top, but not much at the end. Looks... well... stouty.

Smell: Ugh. Good Lord. So much coffee... fully loaded with it. Roast. Maybe notes of chocolate. The coffee dominates and permeates all around.

Taste/feel: Like the smell, but the feel puts it to another level -- perfectly silky and creamy and way too drinkable. The coffee is at the forefront, of course, with a bit of chocolate sweetness. A touch bitter, but well balanced as a whole. If you love coffee in your stouts, youll fall in love with this as I have.

An utterly incredible beer worthy of a pick up. The rating is among Shorts highest for a reason... I thought their Mystery Oatmeal Stout was awesome, but this is actually a little bit better. Dont bother putting socks on before trying this beer, because itll knock them right off anyway.

Cheesy? Dont care. Just drink it, damn you.
This truly is like drinking a cup of coffee. Very good beer. Another one to love from these guys.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2015 re-rate 6/15  left at 4.0...great aroma  coffee  roast  mmmmm....................................recd in trade from ?? Damn good beer. great aroma of coffee with chocolate on top of that. dark pour. palate is soft and creamy. Usually not a fan of cream stouts, but this was done perfectly - cream, coffee, roast, and cocoa in taste. well done!

Bottle poured a very dark brown bordering on black with a thin coat of tan head that fell right off. Aroma has rich coffee, dark malt, some roast, and cream. Mouth feel is medium heavy with a lower side carbonation. Flavor brews up a nice strong coffee, sugar sweetness not bitterness, creamy lactose, chocolate, and a hanging smooth finish. Very rich and on point for a sweet coffee beer delivering loads of flavor!

On tap at HopCat in East Lansing. It pours a nice incredibly dark brown/black with a thin mocha head that laces very nicely. Smells very heavy of ground coffee with the refreshing aroma of espresso. Taste is very solid. Roasted malt and coffee come through on the front, with the espresso carrying it through to the finish. The mouth feel, although good, is a little thin for the aroma and taste. This aspect is the only miss on the beer.

Pours black with a brown head and strong sweet coffee java aroma. Taste is sweet, lots of coffee, espresso, vanilla, and roasted malt with a creamy, sweet coffee chocolate finish. Excellent, tasty stout, nice coffee cream flavors that comes together nicely

From the bottle, pours a dark black color with no head. Nose is sweet, with deep roasted coffee and malted chocolate. Taste is a deep sweet chocolate roasted flavor, with vanilla notes. Absolutely tasteful and full of flavor. Lightly carbonated, and ends on a deep sweet coffee, chocolate cream notes. A great well balanced coffee stout. Quaff store 9 / 10
12 ounce bottle thanks to umich03jm. Pours a real dark brown with a thick khaki head. Tons of coffee in the aroma. Lots of coffee and cream in the taste. I was pretty blown away by this.

On tap, served in a pint glass at Slows.

My pour of Cup A Joe arrives without much visual fanfare.  The beer itself is very thick dark brown color, and there is just a little wisp of a light brown head.  

The coffee in the aroma hits my nose hard.  The Higher Grounds espresso provides a pleasant, earthy espresso tone with underlying notes of cocoa and tobacco.  Medium roasted malt, some dark chocolate, and sweet cream are also noticeable.

By no means is this a complex beer, but each sip is packed full of coffee, cream, and malt, as advertised.  The coffee used to make this beer is of good quality and provides a smoothness I would like in my coffee in the morning.  The cream adds a sweetness that cuts the bitterness from the coffee and accentuates the chocolate flavors more.  The roasted malt provides a nice backbone for the whole experience without really getting in the way.

The creamy nature of the mouthfeel really puts this mouthfeel over the top.  It is clear that the creme and the way this beer is made allow for such a luxurious and rich feel.  The carbonation is smooth, and a residual sweetness stays on the lips after each sip.

Living in Michigan definitely has its perks.  Being able to drink Shorts on tap is definitely one of them.  I would go so far as to say that this is one of the best 7% coffee stouts I have had.  However, the bottle I had was absolutely putrid.  It was not old but had clearly refermented into an undrinkable mess.  Drinking Shorts on tap is the only way to go.

Very roasty with burnt coffee flavors and a slight creaminess.  Lacks a bit in complexity, but still a tasty straightforward beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour is jet black with virtually no head. Nose is a bit artificial, artificial vanilla, overly sweet malt an sugar, and used coffee grounds. Taste is just as bad, overly sweet, under attenuated malt and coffee mess. Virtually no carb and extremely oily and slick feel.
Pours jet black with a thin dark mocha colored head. Aroma is espresso, dark chocolate, and toffee. Taste is rich espresso, dark chocolate, cream, toffee, and charred wood.
Great stuff. Aroma is big roast and coffee, chocolate, and some lactose. Pour is jet black and oily with a tan head. Flavor is iced coffee, chocolate, semi-sweet and fully delicious. Great!!

Wow this beer was good - thanks OmegaX! It had black-as-oil pour and a thin tan head. The smell was of ash, cold-pressed coffee and dark chocolate. The taste was so smooth and creamy, just lots of coffee and chocolate with a pleasant bitterness to balance it all out. Stout + coffee + lactose = greatness.

12oz bottle thanks to Timbo 
Appearance: Pours black with a small tan head that dissipates quickly, no head 
Aroma: Dark roast coffee and chocolate 
Taste: Roasted malts, roast coffee, chocolate and ashy 
Very nice, if you like coffee.

Tap at Churchkey for CBC thanks to biggirlpanties. Pours a clear, deeper brown. Weak head. Nose is diacetyl, big dairy, milk chocolate, creamer. Taste is doughnut, Hershey chocolate syrup, heavy soil and dirt. Mealy, slick body from the dairy character.

murky sepia, thin oily cap. Blueberry, diacetyl, and chocolate nose. Charry front, blueberry and diacetyl forming cheesecake, light chocolate and char mid, liquor like creme brûlée candy finish. Thin and sticky sugar finish, light throat burn

Flavourful milk stout with good shot of coffee. Pours with basically no head. Nose is sweet malts and coffee. Mouthfeel is slick. Taste is coffee and sweet milk sugars.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared by Bri and Courtney, huge thanks for cracking this awesome coffee brew. Poured jet black with thin beige head. Very lasting foam with great lacing. Aromas are tons of earthy pepper, green coffee, espresso, milk chocolate, and roast. Flavor is about the same with lots of mocha and green vegetable notes. Creamy mouthfeel with medium body. One of the best coffee beers I have tried so far. Reminded me of cubano espresso from cigar city but more coffee and balance.
Bottle. Deep dark pour with thin chocolate colored head. Warming chocolate and coffee. A bit too astringent.

12oz bottle, thanks to umich03jm. Totally black color. Thin darker brown head. Leaves good lace. Some spray of lace. Good mildly chewier body, medium to big. Reasonable, light / medium carbonation. More dry overall, nothing sticky. Great roasty coffee flavor. Cremey indeed. Decent bitter taste, but big sweetness in the finish. Light sweet finish. Fine coffee creme stout. I just prefer my coffee straight, hold the creme.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye ...pour is dark black with a thin tan head that fades away..Nose is.coffee,chocolate,cane sugar,caramel,fig..Taste is sweet caramel,sugar,coffee grounds,espresso, vanilla,very smooth,milk chocolate..palate is vanilla and coffee..Very solid beer..Im sure this is pretty aged since the head faded very quickly.

Bottle from trade with umich03jm. Black pour, low disappearing head, and a surprisingly light aroma that mostly consists of coffee  first, and roasted malt in the background. Flavor is also relatively light, with a balance of coffee and roasted malt. Slightly sweet. Soft carbonation and light but not thin on the palate. Very little bitterness here, and finishes sweet. Easy to drink but doesnt really stand out.

Crazy strong coffee aroma and dark black pour with a complex taste and lingering mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2013 Pours a dark black color with a small head that quickly fades.  The aroma is mainly freshly brewed coffee but you can also pick up chocolate and a light creaminess.  Taste is great.  Very lightly roasted, fresh coffee flavor with good amount of slightly sweetened chocolate and cream.  The perfect amount of bitter and sweet balance for a coffee stout.  Fairly thick mouthfeel and incredibly smooth.  Really great stout.  This tastes much better than I remember it tasting last year.
Bottle pours jet black. Thick tan head. Aroma us big roast morning coffee. Taste is sweet cold creamy coffee.
Pours black w tan head, nice looking beer.  Strong coffee scent.  Taste is coffee, although not as strong as expected, roasty and pretty sweet.  Very smooth and syrupy.

12 oz bottle into a DFH signature glass. I enjoyed 2011 vintage last year but never reviewed it. Thanks steimie!

A - Black body with a two finger mocha head. Foam sticks around for a long time. Excellent lacing and retention.

S - Plenty of coffee. Roasty, bitter and slightly sweet . That is about it actually. 

T - Rich and roasty coffee beans and sweet milk sugar. Again, just coffee...but its so delicious. This might be my favorite "coffee beer" but its certainly not the best "coffee stout". Aftertaste is of bitter coffee beans.

M - Medium bodied and creamy. Carbonation is on the low side.

O - Shorts certainly has a skill for making beers which meet their descriptions. While this beer lacks the flavors and aromas that I would normally associate with a stout, this is spot on like a good cup of coffee with some cream. Phenomenal execution!

Bottle pour to snifter.  Dark, dark, dark brown with small head.  Big coffee aroma.  Fresh roasted coffee taste with hint of sugar and cream to take the edge of the bitterness.  I liked the single bottle that I bought...hope the store has a six-pack with my name on it.

Aroma is fantastic, strong coffee notes, some chocolate and vanilla sweetness. Appearance is dark as night, dark brown head, not much of that though. Taste is rich coffee, the taste is like the smell of coffee being ground at the grocery store, its unlike any stout Ive ever drank. Mouthfeel is malty but a little to carbonated to be perfect. Overall, I took a chance on this because I usually dont like Shorts, this was a welcome surprise.

12oz bottle from kalamazoo megabev.  Deep deep brown almost black pour.  Head was dark brown, about a sixteenth of an inch high, and so thick it looked like ground grain resting on top of the beer.  Sweet coffee and cocoa scent, slightly sweeter than the aroma of Founders Breakfast Stout but very similar.  Low carbonation and thick, dense, frothy mouth feel.  Sweet at first, reminiscent of freshly roasted, bold, nutty coffee, with some sweet vanilla.  Finish was a bit astringent but not overbearing, and left a dry sticky feeling, hints of vanilla flavor as well.

26th February 2011Opaque dark brown beer, tidy brown head. Nose of fresh black coffee. Fairly neutral palate. Fresh black coffee, not bitter but very slightly sour. Some lactose takes the edge off the coffee. Whisper of hop fruits in the finish but this beer is all about the coffee and its done well.
UPDATED: NOV 9, 2013 Bottle from Nate. Pours dark brown with a white head. A lot of espresso coffee, raisin, and  cocoa. Taste sweet espresso and toasted malts. Pretty good.

I love Shorts beer, but this one is their worst. Hard to choke down this bag of bitter coffee beans. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Midnight brown with a medium brown crown and thick ass lacing.  Aroma of coffee, dark roasted malts and some sweetness and acidity to boot.  Taste of coffee, roasted malt, lactose and something sour.  Finishes up a cross between sweet and acidic.

Pours inky black with one finger of dark tan coffee brown head.  Has an intense coffee roast to the nose with notes of mocha and caramel.  Super coffee character,  some fruit skins and an acidic roast character.  Light body with a noticeable acidity.

Thanks to afdempse for sharing this great beer.

A: Deep black, beige head, big lacing

S: Coffee! Seriously...If you can get past the intense aromas of fresh roasting coffee, you may find some roasted malt scents.

T: Again, roasted coffee. Fresh and delicious. What this beer lacks in complexity it makes up for by being simply delicious. You must love coffee to thoroughly enjoy this beer.

M: Somewhat thin feel, great crisp carbonation.

D: Highly recommended. I could have a few of these.

Bottle, thanks Justin!   Black with a small ring of tan lace.  Nose is heavy coffee grounds, some bakers chocolate, pepper, cedar, roasted malts.  Similar flavor, tastes kinda like watered down coffee with a couple spoonfuls of sugar.  A little cream in the finish. One of the better Shorts experiences of recent memory though mainly because this was not infected.

Draft to oversized snifter. Looks good; pitch black with low carbonation and nice lacing. Smells great! One of the best coffee shouts Ive ever smelled. Tastes pretty good, but not as good as it smells. Mouthfeel is decent. Pretty good, but I wish the taste was as good as the smell.
Dissapointing for me.  Taste is coffee grounds and milk.  The base beer is mostly hidden but the strong spent coffee taste.   Medium sweet and silky palate but the flavor is off.
And........ This is a cup of coffee beer. Smells like a cup of coffee and tastes like a too. A gimmick that works well but still a gimmick
Pours russet brown-black into snifter. Smells of espresso, spent grain, oats and molasses. Tastes the same. Damn good.
12oz bottle shared by wesirs. Dark pour with some roasted coffee and some mild smoke.  Taste was bitter coffee followed by a tangy sourness unfortunately. This would have been great.

12oz bottle. Rating #185. Dark black with a decent head. Huge roast aroma, ashy and a little smoky. Flavor was a bit off, more dark roast, a little coffee, but there was a bit of sourness as well. It seemed a little contaminated/infected, too bad. (2356)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
Originally reviewed: 3/27/11. I had received a boxload of Shorts earlier this year and only 1/4 of what I had tried was not infected. I thought surely this beer, with its A- average, would be alright. I was anticipating it greatly, as coffee stouts are one of my favorites. Alas, it did not deliver. And because Shorts has horrible quality control and I am not alone in my experience with this , I will review nonetheless. 

Split this with my wife. Poured my allotment into a chalice. Pours a very dark black, with the thinnest of tan heads on top. No lace. The nose is the best part of this beer. With the other infected Shorts brews, I could sense it in the aroma, not with this one. This misled me into believing it was indeed an alright beer. Big notes of freshly-ground coffee, some chocolate, and roasted malts. What I expected and hoped for. 

The mouth is overly-carbonated for the style. I like a bit more smoothness and heft. This one was bordering spritzy and thin. Eh. The flavor is where this fell flat. Some coffee is notes, but it is so overpowered by sourness, that I cant even begin to pull out other flavors. Chocolate? Not so much. Sweet cream? Nope. Sour vinegar? Bingo! Thats it. "Beer," meet drain. What a mess this was. I am honestly done with this brewery. Theres only a few breweries overall that I will write off. This one made the list.

Bottle with pat and Linh. Pours a deep brown body with light brown lacing with carbonation. Aroma is strong coffee and espresso and light sweet roast.  Mouthfeel is medium with nice coffee roast flavor.
On tap, black coal color minimal head. Huge coffee espresso in the nose. Full bodied lots of dark malts mixed with coffee. Impressive amounts of coffee on this one, good beer.
12 ounce bottle pour.  Black color with a tan head.  As advertised coffee and creamy.  A nice stout.  Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Deep black body with a nice one inch chocolate brown head. No lacing, but the head receded to a hearty skim that maintained its froth throughout.

S: Bold, roasted coffee. Hints of expresso, bittersweet chocolate and a nice sweet cream undercurrent.

T: Much like the nose, this is definitely coffee forward. A nice earthy, smokey blend of roasted coffee pleases the palate. The chocolate and sweet cream help to balance the coffee and results in a surprisingly delicate experience considering the boldness of the roasted coffee in the nose.

M: Perhaps the biggest flaw is the weight of the body. While the lightness makes this beer incredibly drinkable, I was hoping for a creamier experience. Otherwise smooth, with a nice lingering finish of lightly bitter coffee.

O: A very nice addition to the world of stouts. Shorts has a very nice blend of coffee and cream here and its a nice treat. Goes well with a chocolate chip cookie.

Thanks to pest for sharing a bottle. The beer pours brown-black with a medium tan head that dissipates steadily. Stringy lacing on the glass. Aroma of black coffee with some chocolatey notes in the background. Medium body with a roasted coffee character and flavors of bittersweet chocolate, malt and a touch of dark fruit. The finish is creamy with a coffee aftertaste. Above average overall.

Small foamy fine dark brown opaque dark brown no visible carbonation.  Strong roasted coffee burnt malt aroma.  Dark malt roasted malt coffee flavor.  Mild start tingly roasted finish.  A decent brew.

Nice malty aroma up front and then as you are starting to drink the coffee smell hits you.  The taste had a nice coffee flavor that some "coffee" stouts lack.  Although I have been a little down on Shorts beers laterly, this one was a good one that I want to get more of.

This beer pours a dark black body with a thin dark tan, bubbly head that settles quickly.  The aroma is of coffee and some sweet caramel, also there is a little funky, almost sour quality in the smell.  It tastes very much like coffee but also with a bit of this off puting sour taste.  I do love sour beers but I totally wasnt expecting anything sour from the taste but I for sure got some weird sourness.  I think this bottles must be a bit old, I wish Shorts put bottled on dates on their beers.  Im am sure if this beer was younger it would be great.  I still get all the awesome coffee notes but the sourness kills almost all the roasty flavors the beer has to offer.

(bottle - 12 oz) Pitch black pour with a thin tan head. Coffee and roasted malts abound in the aroma with a very sweet cream and chocolate note coming up under it. Flavor starts off with lots of coffee and espresso leading into a big roasted and burnt malt middle. Light sweetness near the finish and the cream really makes it smooth and silky. Really good.

Draft at Bixlers Lodge poured dark brown with thin tan head.  Aroma of roasted coffee.  Flavor dominated by sweetened coffee with cream, a hint of chocolate, and a slightly bitter espresso finish.  Paired very well with my filet mignon with bearnaise sauce and a side of brown rice.
12oz from notes, I will re re rate this once I try an uninfected bottle.  So yeah, infected for sure, super high carbonation, bitter with no flavor at all.

Ported from BA.


Appearance:
Dark brown, opaque, and a small amount of tan head. Pretty standard for the style.

Smell:
Coffee and condensed milk. Slightly sweet. Its kind of like a a creamy iced coffee smell. No hop presence here.

Taste:
Still, no noticeable hops, but no issues here. Lots of coffee, some creamy milkiness hanging around with it. Again, like a coffee with cream. Thats the best way to describe this. Semi sweet with some chocolate notes in the background too.

Mouthfeel: 
Thickish, more like the milk than the coffee. I suspect that lactose is an ingredient here. Mediumish carbonation.

Overall:
Not bad, but Ill admit that I take my coffee black. Milk stouts have never been my thing, but this is certainly ranking above most of them.

Deep, absolute pitch black coloured body with no head at all and a very oily look - crazy deep, just like a nice [used] motor oil. Aroma of super pungent coffee, roasted malt, peanuts, walnuts, anise and a ton more roasted coffee. Medium-bodied; Super strong soy sauce, Worcestershire, mushrooms and meaty flavours abound with some roasted coffee, a lot of pungent roasted malt, alcohol and a bit more anisey and licorice flavours - strong as hell and not necessarily in a good way. Aftertaste is very strong with a vibrant mushroom and meaty taste along with roasted coffee. Overall, a strong and pungent beer with a lot of deep flavours that dont go over so well. Nice and strong tasting, but just not for me. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Merchants in Dearborn, Michigan on 16-January-2011 sampled at home in Washington on 19-September-2011.

12oz bottle thanks to my good friend raveskdr. Poured a pitch black, no head at all. Aroma was burnt, roasted coffee. Flavor was coffee, like a cold straight, black coffee. Booze non-existent. Pretty good, but Ive had better coffee stouts before. Worth checking out.
Bottle:  Pours dark brown/black with no head.  Heavy aroms of coffee with a hint of chocolate.  Sweet taste of coffee.  Very good.

I have tried this a couple times, I believe this bottle is thanks to wnoble.  Dar dark brown, almost black pour, tan head.  Aroma is huge on the coffee, almost strictly espresso, with some notes of sweet roasted malt.  Flavor is similar, lots of coffee, but with a sharper roasted edge, some cream, sweet chocolate, and an odd tartness.  I nice enjoyable coffee beer, if that is something that you like.

12oz bottle from deyholla, thanks Derek! Pours a pitch black body with a thin, dark brown head that dissipates quickly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is straight up espresso and coffee grounds with some dark chocolate, cream, smoke, bitter coffee, and a touch of earth. A few dark fruits and licorice in there too. Flavor is sweet and big on the coffee and espresso with some sweeter dark chocolates. Bitter coffees, some earthy hops, and milky, creamy chocolates as well. Finishes dry and lightly bitter with plenty of coffee and cream along with a nice chocolate-dark fruit. Lengthy aftertaste following a medium, smooth body and moderate carbonation. Overall, a pretty solid beer. Plenty of cream and coffee flavor with a really nice chocolate and roasty bitterness. Very creamy and easy drinking, nice one.

Bottle. Pours nearly black with a small tan head. Aroma is coffee and burnt wood. Flavor is plums, grapes, coffee, cocoa, and bananas. Light/medium fluffy mouthfeel. If the palate was better this beer would be great.
espresso, molasses. black with a light tan head,  coffee, vanilla, molasses, plums, cherries.   medium palate
Pours a dark brown with a little white head. Tons of espresso coffee, raisins, cocoa. Taste sweet expresso and toasted malts. Overall a solid brew
Well since I dont really care for much coffee I dont feel right giving my opinion on this one. For what it is its great, but for a none coffee drinker not so much.

The beer is dark black with a very dark tan head. There is tons of carbonation spilling over the glas rising at least 5 fingers. It falls pretty quickly but does leave a nice soapy head. The lacing is nice. 

The aroma is all coffee, does not leave room for anything else. The smell is cold coffee that has been sitting for a while, a little roasitness left.

The taste is much lighter than the coffee aroma, but its still all coffee, if it was as strong it would not have been drinkabile. This is very smooth and drinkable.

The feel is nice, with a lasting a flavor and a very dry finish.
tasting on 3/19/11.  black pour with a thin tan head.  big coffee nose with oats.  medium creamy body with coffee, vanilla, and oat body.  sweet finish with dry oats, roasted coffee and chocolate.

Thick, heavy burnt roasty coffee.  I love coffee stouts, and this one brings the coffee, but it doesnt have a particularly wonderful coffee smell, merely an average one.  I wish the lactic sweetener was more prevalent in cutting the taste, because the body is pretty good on this one.  Good but just off the mark of great.

12 oz. Thanks ben! Pours black with a loose burnt tan head. Big coffee and alkaline battery nose. Creamy medium body with some lively carb. Cheap coffee and expensive batteries on the mid palate. Long tangy battery finish.

Pours black (yeah no shit) with nearly no head.  Aroma is some coffee, lots of chocolate, and sweet sugary creme stout nose with some bready and toasty malt character.  no hop aroma.  Taste is sweet and nearly tart with roasty and lacto sweet character.  malt sweetness lingers.  Palate is medium bodied with a smooth lightly carbonated mouthfeel that lingers.  very drinkable.  I liked this one.

Bottle pours deep brown/black with a thin beige head.  Aroma shows notes of coffee, moderate roast, chocolate and creamy lactose.  Flavor shows the same, but the coffee feels artifical at this point like a sweet mocha syrup.

Appearance: Pours a viscous dark brown with no head.

Aroma: Coffee, roast, soy sauce.

Taste: Black coffee with sugar.

Mouthfeel: Thick with modest carbonation.

Overall: Ok-ish.  It wasnt infected ;-), it didnt have stale grinds, but it didnt knock my socks off.
Maybe infection creeping in, not one of my fav styles. still have a few of these lying around, I might just throw them out.

Part of the 13 Shorts in one night tasting at the Mikes on 2/18/11.  Thanks Mike.  Nose sweet like milk, and coffee.  Taste clean coffee and mid/dark sweetness.  Clean finish.  Leftovers are cool milk.   
*Kuhlua (sp?) added to the beer was amazing!
nice stout, just as good as i remember. very creamy and yummy, nice coffee profile, very drinkable and doesnt get boring. excellent brew.

This poured a very dark brown color almost black with a beige head. Aroma was lots and lots of dark roasted coffee with a strange astringent funk. Flavor was medium coffee flavors, light chocolate,a nd some light sourness that I believe is due to infection. This is the first of their beers that I have had that tasted infected, but I have heard of others.

Bottle.  Pours an opaque black.  Very small tan head.  Small filmy retention.  Strong roasty aroma of black coffee.  Flavor is of coffee, but without the bitterness.  The milkiness replaces the bitterness.  I love the roasty coffee flavor, but wish the palate was just a tad thicker.  Additionally would like less cream.  Without the creme this would be a beast of a stout.

Bottle.  Pours a dark black with a large beige and tan head.  Toast and caramel cream candies on the nose.  Boozy coffee aromas.  Slight sour plum notes made me think that Id gotten an infected bottle.  Roast, toast, and coffee, lightly bitter cocoa on the finish.

Tasted on 1/30/11 from a 12oz bottle obtained in a trade, bottled on 12/1/10.  Pours opaque and oily black with a thin tan head that recedes to a very thin collar of lace.  The nose is very freshly roasted and earthy coffee along with some molasses and burnt brown sugar and light nuttiness.  The flavor is more acidic than the nose would have suggested, but with all of the same roasted coffee, molasses, and nutty qualities.  The body is medium with light carbonation and a very long roasted coffee finish.

Poured into a pint glass. Thanks to OHLRangers for this one.

4.5 A: Black color. Many fingers of "fuzzy" medium brown head that retains well, but doesnt lace much.

4.5 S: Dark roast coffee up front. Malty sweetness next with lots of lactose. Roasted barley burtness and dark chocolate.

4.5 T: Surprisingly, there isnt much bitterness from the hops or the coffee. Rather, this is closer to the "coffee creme stout" they were going for. Medium roast coffee, mocha, sourish lactose sweetness makes this one quite tasty.

5.0 M: Heavier medium body. Good carbonation even though it originally appeared to be overcarbed. Very creamy, which I love.

5.0 D: Deee-licious. Really a great brew. Tastes just like it should given what they were going for. Drinks like a 5% brew and, in fact, I was shocked when I saw it was 8%.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-28-2010 03:10:11

Loved this beer. Poured from bottle with no head and nearly opaque black. You can smell the coffee and subtle roasty notes. Good alcohol content and hidden very well. Top notch. Will def drink more of this again. Soon.

12 oz bottle: Appearance is a black pour with a small tan head that doesnt stick around for very long.  A rich coffee and malt aroma wafting up from the glass, roasted scents, and a bit of caramel.  Taste is coffee heavy, roasted malts, somewhat slippery,  and chocolate.  Palate has a lingering coffee and malts texture.  Overall, Really great beer overall.  I like this one.  Cheers!

Pours thick oily black with thin tan head, aroma is big notes of chocolate, sweet cream, coffee, and some roast.  Taste is thick iced coffee, leading into sweet caramel, cream, and some chocolate notes.  Finishes roasty, more coffee, and very nice and bitter.  Excellent brew, a bit one sided but does the coffee extremely well.  Delicious, a morning beer for sure!

12 oz bottle from my trip to Michigan. Awesome! Pours a near pitchblack silky smooth pour, dark and lucious, a small brown head dies to a clinging small ring. Opaque and it means buisness. Aromas are a rich roasty coffee and cream blend, milky lactose sugars mix with roasty earthy coffee beans, Dunkin Donuts blend, earthy roasted beans, a touch of earthy smoke, chocolate. A nice sweetness mixes in, balances well. Big on aroma and coffee. Initial is medium bodied, perhaps a bit lighter, roasted and sweet, actually the sweetness takes over with lactose, chocolate, coffee grounds and roasty beans mix in. A bit light in body, truly tastes like coffee and cream though. A healthy sweetness cuts in, a touch of nuttiness, earthy, toffee, some decent coffee grounds. Vanilla and cream, lactose sweetness and light cocoa. Highly rich aroma leads way to an easily quaffable sweet stout that tastes very close to an iced sweetened coffee with cream. Quite flavorful, but lighter end of medium bodied. Quite nice, lingering roast and cream, sweetness. Mmmmm. Amazing this weighs in at 8 ABV! Doesnt taste anything like it..

Bottle.  Great beer, up there with the best of coffee stouts.  Exceptionally smooth and creamy, almost like eating a truffle, super smooth dark chocolate, creme, softer black coffee and sugar.  Perhaps just a bit too smooth in the flavor, could use just a touch more contrast which is odd to say of something so fine.  Medium fluffy milky smooth body.  Job well done here.

Bottle.  Pours near black with no head or appearance of carbonation.  Coffee grounds dominate the aroma.  Flavors consist of coffee, milk chocolate, vanilla creme and a hint of smoke.  Very sweet finish that dulls nicely from the lingering coffee bitterness.  Creamy texture with very light carbonation.  Best enjoyed when your in the mood for something heavier in body.

Poured into my Delirium snifter glass I noticed that the texture was pretty thick. Syrupy and oily with a thin brown head. The aroma had hints of roasted coffee bean, espresso and vanilla, a delicious combo I could fall for every time. The flavor however was something totally out of left field. Black Olive.... Thats right, black olives came through in the flavor. I didnt catch it at first, probably because I dont eat olives ever, but once The Ferm mentioned it I totally tasted it. It was quite bizarre to say the least. It had the coffee and lactose flavors as well, but black olives really took center stage on this one. I might be inclined to get more of this, but I wouldnt go out of my way to be truthful. It was a great tasting experience, but olives are meant for salads and pizza, not in my beer.

BIG thanks to Jim for this brew!

A- Body is an opaque thick dark brown-nearly black hue. Pours with a one finger or so dark brown soapy head that quickly fades to a thin collar. Little to no lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Very strong coffee with a lot of dark roasted malt being dominant in the nose-not completely black coffee as there is a semisweet essence milk (coffee creamer)

T-Taste is much more balanced than the nose. The milk sugar comes through initially with a really big roasted malt backbone. The finish is conistent with the initial flavor but slightly sweeter. A mild roasted malt bitterness lingers.

M- Low to medium carbonation and a fairly thick body that is smooth an creamy-well done.

D- This really comes across as a good imperial milk/coffee stout. The alcohol is very well hidden and this is a very tasty well done, tasty brew from shorts.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-08-2010 03:01:16
Move over Bells. Shorts is taking over as Michigans best. This one is more complex than Bells Java Stout. Yummy.

Pretty typical deep brown pour with just a small, quickly dissipating layer of tan foam.

Aroma is sweet coffee.  Flavor has some additional milky/creamy flavors along with the coffee notes... finishes with a nice roasty bitterness.

Mouthfeel is smooth, but I might prefer just a tad more carbonation. Drinkability is fairly high - nothing too extreme here and the alcohol is hidden well so I could see myself putting back a couple of these.

I had very high hopes for this one, but the coffee flavor was a bit underwhelming and sweeter than I expected.  It is a good beer nonetheless and something I would drink again.

Draft sample. Poured black color and an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy dark chocolate malt and coffee aroma. Medium to full body with with a smooth rich texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy roasted coffee and dark chocolate flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. Good complex beer.

Bottle courtesy of pailhead. Dark dark black color with a rich brown head. Aroma is beautiful! Loads of roasted coffee, toasted notes, black malts and lots more coffee! Flavor is like a cup of the blackest coffee Grandfather ever poured. Wow, rich coffee, burnt malts, a tad bit nutty and some harsh chocolate cream. This is very good but is a little harsh on the finish. Nice!
Bottle from Cavie.  Dark pour with no head.  Aroma is earthy, dirty coffee, a little chocolate, and roasted.  Taste is really coffee, dirty, beans, and bitter.

12 oz bottle, bought as a single. Roasty and bitter, ever-so-tart and acidic (intentionally? hmm) with coffee notes but not overwhelmingly so. little head and carbonation, leaving it smelling and feeling initially thick. some milk chocolate throughout, and its a decently enjoyable beer. thins out in the finish, and more sweetened coffee is apparent as the alcohol evaporates off the tongue. good beer, but im glad i dont have a whole six-pack of it.

Bottle pours pitch black with no head.  After I poured it it looked like it was starting to show signs of head formation around the edges.  But nothing.  Aroma is layered.  Upfront I detect caramalt very strongly, then it leads very quickly to dark roasted coffee.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Flavors are what you would expect for a brew like this.  But it goes beyond that and doesnt disappoint.  Dark roast coffee, bittersweet chocolate, caramalt, and finishes with dark roast coffee that lingers on the palate for a while.  Awesome.

Pours inky black with an extremely dark brown but small head.  Lacing is towards minimal.  Nose is intense, full of roasty black coffee with subtler hints of chocolate and creme.  Mouthfeel is thinner, almost zero carbonation, malty, sweet, and a bit of lactic sourness.  Barely drinkable; if I was desperate I could choke it down but thankfully Im not.  Tastes like a weak attempt at Southern Tier Creme Brulee Stout or the incomparable Kuhnhenn Creme Brulee Java Stout.

Bottle thanks to Styles. Pours black with tan head. Nose of fresh coffee grounds, vanilla and toasted chocolate malts. Taste is strong fresh coffee grounds, sweet cream, vanilla and toasted chocolate malts. Medium body.

12 oz bottle pour.  Densely black body, small dark brown head which diminished very quickly.  Lots of coffee in the nose, roast malt, lactose.  Bit less coffee in flavor, but definitely still a huge player, roast & choco malt.  Mid-Full body, nice long, dry finish.  One of the better coffee beers Ive had, a style Im not a huge fan of.

Bottle purchased from Salut in Kalamazoo, Mich.  Aroma is strong of  chocolate and coffee.  Taste is also coffee, chocolate and dark, roasted malt.  A solid beer, but couldve used a little more carbonation.  It seemed a little flat to me.  But, having said that, Im glad I have 11 more to go.

A: Pours very dark with a nice tan-colored head and a tiny amount of lacing as it goes down.

S: Lots of coffee up front here. A little bit of chocolate and alcohol, but straight-up black coffee is definitely what dominates.

T: Coffee and darker chocolate along with a little bit of roasted-malt sweetness. A bit of extra sugar and hints of vanilla.

M: Fairly full-bodied, quite creamy, and not too much carbonation.

D: Quite drinkable. Not the best coffee beer that Ive had, but definitely a very worthy one.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-30-2009

Growler from Shorts...This stout pours dark black with a decent tan head. The aroma is awesome and very "Shortsy" as sour Pete said - delicious sweet caramel and coffee notes. The flavor is amazingly smooth for the ABV with a rich creamy body and notes of coffee and roasted malts.

12oz bottle as a sweet extra from pantanap. thanks, kan! pours an oily, black with a thick, creamy, slightly fizzy brown head and light lacing. aroma is great with overwhelming, black, roasted coffee, bitter chocolate, sweet, sugary creamer and hints of dark fruits with a bit of ash. flavor is excellent as well with all manor of coffee notes including dark, black, roasted beans, herbal grinds, and slightly bitter, citric mexican blend backed by sweet caramel, nutella spread, and charred malts with a bittersweet, mocha finish. there is a definite lactose sugar/lactic acid component (beginnings if infection?) but it really does work in this brew to balance the bitterness of the coffee and the sweetness of the chocolate. palate is the only letdown with this one as its definitely too highly carbonated to be smooth on the palate (again, possible infection?) and ends up faily ligh bodied. overall, a very well executed coffee stout that would be close to greatness with a bit less fizz.

A solid pour into my 25cl tulip glass produces a four-finger thick, richly brown colored head.  The beer is an almost perfectly black color and remains opaque even when held up directly to the light.  As I pour this beer the aroma of deeply roasted, almost acrid roast coffee is noticeable.  A more focused inspection of the nose yields some weird aromatic combinations.  Coffee definitely plays a big role here, but there seems to be a burnt vegetal edge to it.  Underneath this is some dark chocolate character with a touch of sweetness to it.  Roasted coffee joins roasted / toasted grain and there is even a hint of cherry character bound up in these roast notes.  A touch too acrid and burnt-vegetal like, but actually the nose isnt really that bad.

Lightly sweet up front and this beer has a definite body to it from the lactose sugar, but the beer also finishes with a big tartness that I at first thought might have been contributed by the burnt grain and coffee, but it is too much and is in fact lactic in character.  Unfortunately another infected brew from Shorts, again it sort of works here somehow.  I wont have any trouble finishing my bottle of this infected brew.  The lactic acid blends pretty harmoniously with the lactose and the big roasted coffee and grain character found here.  Both the roast character and the lactic acid compete with the lactose sweetness, such that the beer almost comes off as being dry.  Somehow the infection has added flavors of cherries to this beer as well.

This is another clearly infected brew that works better than it actually should.  Again, if you are open to the experience then give it a go, but if you are looking for a Coffee Crème Stout then look else-where.

Bottle 12fl.oz.Clear dark brown color with a average to large, creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light brown head. Aroma is heavy malty, burnt, chocolate, strong coffee, vanilla notes. Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, berry notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100709]

12 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is coffee and dark roasted malt. Herbal, citric and dark bitter coffee and hops. Dark chocolate and roasted malt. Dark coffee and roasted malt finish.

pitch dark smooth light brown head.
coffe dominates the aroma. roasted coffe, a litlle more bitter than roasted coffee. sweet caramelly note. something that might be wood?
flavor is coffee, roasted stuff, faint sourness or citrussy or flowery note, could be hops or wood. quite coffe bitter impression.

Bottled. Pitch black coloured. Dark brown dense head. Aroma of roast, light coffee, brown sugar, light liqourice and some vanilla. Flavour of coffee, berries, sweetness, spice and light roast. Medium to full bodied. Sweet and cocoaish end.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of daknole. Pours a pitch black with a light brown head. Lots of dark roast coffee and vanilla in the nose. Rather solid body with a heavy carbonation. Again dark hard roasted malts, some raisins and other dark fruits. Theres a slight tartness lurking underneath. No real bitterness though. 090710

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a huge dark brown head. The aroma has strong notes of coffee and vanilla, as well as medium notes of roasted malt. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of coffee, roasted malt, wood, and milk, as well as some vanilla, leading to a dry roasted finish. Powerful body.
Bottle. Pitch black with a creamy tan head. The aroma is loads of coffee, caramel and roasted malt. Heavy coffee, some tobacco and caramel in the flavour. Long bitter coffee espresso like finish.

bottle by way of nbutler on 1/2/2010. 

pours an orange shade of black with an orange tinted light brown head. 

it smells predominantly of spent coffee grounds, hazelnuts, butter/cocoa butter, umami/wet wood, roast, grass and a  touch of spiciness. 

the flavor follows suit... lots of wet coffee grounds and earth. terribly one dimensional.... and delicious!

the body has a touch of heft (lactose?) but remains easy to put away. 8/4/7/4/16/3.9

Bottle. Pours an extremely dark brown color with a nice big tan head. The aroma is amazing on this one! Strong notes of coffe, dark chocolate, vanilla, and an almost leathery smell (in a good way). The taste is like drinking a cold dark roast coffee with a shot of espresso. The coffee takes center stage and ends with a slight bitterness followed by an almost milk chocolate flavor. Medium/heavy mouthfeel. Good carbonation.

Well, this definitely stays true to the name.  Pours a nice thick black with really thick dark tan head, decent lacing and retention.  Aroma smacks you in the face with coffee, but its not a cup that I would be all that happy to drink.  Slight other aroma of almost burnt malt and nutty character.  Flavor matches all too well, but has a creamy sweet property to it that makes it a pretty pleasant drink.  Mouthfeel is heavy, but surprisingly dry.

Bottle poured a clear dark brown with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of coffee, bitter chocolate, roasted malt and light vanilla. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of roasted malt, coffee, bitter chocolate and light vanilla with a smooth dry lingering coffee finish.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2010 12oz bottle. Pours black with a huge bubbly brown head. Nose is full of black coffee, roasted malts. Flavor is of bitter coffee, slightly creamy and followed by sours flavors as well which kind of masked by the coffee. Cant get over the sourness. Definately infected bottle.

Served from a 12 oz bonus bottle from awiseman01. The appearance is deep cloudy black with a huge foamy medium brown head. The aromas are rich with freshly roasted coffee beans, a medium roast. Some powdered cream and chocolate notes are in the nose as well. The flavors are nice with sugar spiked coffee with a light dose of cream. A fair touch of cola flavors in there as well. The mouth is uber effervescent and really distracting from the flavors. This seems to be very common in all of the Shorts beers I have had and I am wondering if this is the intention or if the store I get them from is handling them poorly.

12 oz. bottle from shawnm213- thanks again, Shawn!  This is my first Shorts brew.  Looks like motor oil right out of the bottle and suddenly an explosively large brown head piles up and foams out of the glass.  Good retention and almost no lace.  Aroma of coffee grounds, roasted malts, burnt toast, and dark chocolate.  Flavor of coffee, roasted malts, tart and dark berry fruits, molasses, and dark chocolate.  Starts roasty and finishes tart with some roast in the background.  Medium-full bodied, with mild carbonation and a mouthfeel somewhere between coffee and juice.  Very unusual but I like it a lot.

This whole 6-pack is a disaster. Every singly bottle so far,has poured with a problem head. I mean a fresh clean glass,that poured a head of foam taking up 90% of the glass,it took about 10 minutes to fill a glass with mostly beer. Aroma was tolerable,much like cold coffee,and a little grain hop zing.Taste has an unpleasant bitterness,almost a sourness,like some lactose went badtasted and felt over carbonated,there is some kind of infection here. Everyone at our Beer club felt the same. Im embarrased to say I traded one of these before I tried it. Seems I got a bad batch,but it is 6 bottles of badness

Bottle from StFun...thanks Josh! - Pours deep and dark with a big foamy tan head. Lots of tobacco, ash, and sweet creaminess. Bitter coffee that transitions into ash, charcoal, and sweet cream that has notes of Irish creme, fruit, and lighter roast coffee. Complex and tasty, but fairly uneven. Glad I had this one once.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a black color with a medium sized light brown foamy head.  Aroma of roasted coffee beans, cream, sugar and malt.  Taste of fresh roasted coffee beans, cream, sugar, malt and chocolate.
Dark pour with a thin off white head. Aroma has burnt espresso and lots of roasted malts. Flavor is lightly bitter and burnt coffee. Little fizzy body and thin overall.

12oz bottle scored via trade.  Pours a medium bodied, opaque black with a very active, basically gushing, creamy beige head.  Aroma of cold coffee, coffee gronds, sour cherries, turbinado sugar.  Flavors of coffee, cola, brown sugar, burnt toast.  Theres a distinct sour flavor, is that coffee, infection or fruit?  I think Im getting a lacto sugar flavor/mouthfeel.  Medium bodied, sweet finish.

Another cool Shorts beer thanks to Timbo. Pours a wonder black color with a thick brown head. The aroma is nice; rich coffee, light sourness. The flavor was probably among those Shorts beers that are off; sweet coffee, sourness, vanilla. Off, but still nice.

Bottle purchased at Sicilianos. The pour is black and the head is thick and tan. Aroma is coffee and cream as expected. Coffee and hops are up front in the flavor, then the chocolate creaminess finishes. Pretty good.

Pours out black with a small tan head. Aroma is of dark roast coffee and a creamy, almost cappuccino note. Taste is straight up coffee, roasted malts, and a little bit of some sweetness lingering in there also. A solid coffee beer, and yet I still have no idea why I like coffee beer, and not coffee.

12oz bottle.   Black with a dark brown head.   The aroma is mostly very black coffee that is a touch oxidized and stale at first, but gets pretty nice when it opens up and warms.   The flavor is much the same, with a ton of coffee that is a touch sour and quite bitter.   The malt is pretty buried under the strong coffee character, and the acidity is high enough to throw things a little out of balance.   Medium bodied with middle of the road carbonation.   Alright coffee brew but not something that I would seek out.

Bottle courtesy iceicebaby. Pours a pretty black color with a solid fluffy brown head. Huge black roasted coffee nose, ash, cacao. Flavor is similar, old black burnt coffee with an additional tart red fruit note. Substantial roasted malt acidity, and no sign of the "creme." Underwhelming. Oily and a little thin.

big thanks to BAs steebo777 for sending this in a trade.  pours greasy black with dense tan head.  the kind of head you cant buy, but receive from someone you love.  nose is heavy coffee and dark roast and char.  taste is more of the same.  this is one of best coffee stouts ive had.  id drink this all week, if they sold it in MN and i wasnt left to trade for it.  damn you michigan brews!

Dark brown almost black pour with tan head.  Aroma is coffee.  Flavor dominates with coffee.  No surprises there. But I was trying to find that "creme" flavor. And I have to say, it was there.  As the beer warmed a bit I noticed a creeping sweetness that distinguished this beer from other coffee stouts.  Alcohol was well-hidden too.  I liked this almost as much as Founders Breakfast Stout. If coffee stouts werent so "been there, done that", it might have gotten a slightly higher rating.  Nevertheless, I would buy this again if it were cold enough outside.

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a fluffy tan head.  Nose is earthy coffee, brown sugar and hay.  Medium body with a sharp lactic tang.  Taste is coffee bean and bitter licorice with hints of dark chocolate.  Not so creamy.

Big thanks to whoever sent me this! I think it was Alexsdad. This is a very challenging beer. It pours very dark brown with a tall fizzy brown head. It has a very strong, acidic aroma of ground coffee, chocolate, and hazelnuts. The flavor is also very powerful and acidic with notes of plum, prunes, and dark roasted coffee beans. The coffee flavors are really overpowering. Ive had another beer from these guys and it was sour and infected. This one seems to lean in that direction too, but I love the coffee.
Pours very dark, big medium brown head, very carbonated. The aroma is coffee, a little sour smell. Doesnt smell as good as the Mystery Stout. The taste is sour

bottle thanks to Deyholla, I think.  Pours black with a huge, light-brown head.  Nose is a robust coffee and ash.  Taste is of delicious coffee.  Lots of coffee.  Mouthfeel is medium-thin.  Very nice,

Bottle: &nbsp Black in color, brownish head, HUGE and fluffy, spotty lacing. &nbsp Rich roasted malts and coffee grounds on the nose. &nbsp Mild sweetness up front, tart, coffee oriented, roasted malts abound. &nbsp Basic stout, slight tartness, big roasted malt flavor, with a hefty coffee background. &nbsp Nothing unusual, but very solid. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Has a coffee bean like sweetness. &nbsp Did I mention coffee? &nbsp Tart coffee finish. &nbsp Lingering roasted malts. &nbsp Very flavorful and coffee oriented. &nbsp Much less a stout than its a coffee beer. &nbsp Thanks Kevin for this one!

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2010 i drank this is a dimly lit bar. it looked dark, smelled decent. tasted like coffee. go figure.

UPDATE 12-8-2010... a little flat.. this thing tasted like a 2 hour old cup of coffee.. literally. i liked it better on tap last year. you better be in the mood for a straight up CUP OF MOTHAFUCKIN COFFEE when you drink this beer.

Shared by a generous RB at tpd975s throwdown in December, 2009. Pours a pitch black color with tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty with roast, coffee, chocolate, brown sugar, burnt toast, toffee. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of chocolate, burnt coffee, roast, light toffee and molasses. Medium to full body with a pleasing malty coffee finish.

A: The pour is black with a nice fluffy mocha colored head. Not much lacing, but what can ya do?

S: This beer makes its presence known. I could smell the coffee as soon as I opened up the bottle. There is a very slight hint of chocolate and roasted malt, but the coffee really steals the show.

T: Once again, the coffee takes center stage. However, the taste has a bit more going on than the nose. There is a very pleasant sweet, cream taste (probably lactose) which adds just an amazing compliment to the coffee. Dark chocolate and roasted malt also make appearances, but again, the coffee is the star.

M: The body is a bit on the thin side, perhaps, but it doesnt ruin the beer at all. Still a medium bodied beer with a fairly creamy and smooth mouthfeel.

D: Ive had several coffee beers and this is easily the best. Great aroma and flavor and a pretty easy drinker too, even at 8% ABV.

Pours dark black with a solid brown head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, lactose, and roasted malt. The palate is effervescent at first, but softens over time making the beer oily and slick over the tongue.  The taste is sweet upfront, a little sour over the tongue and finishes with a lasting coffee bitterness. I found the lactose to be over powering and the initial strong carbonation to be uncharacteristic of most stouts. It mellowed as it warmed, but left me unimpressed.

12oz bottle courtesy of Dakine. Pours an opaque black color with a medium tan head that has good retention. The aroma is pure coffee and espresso. The flavor is more of the same, lightly sweetened espresso with a shot of coffee liquor. The mouthfeel is full and smooth, there is a trace of acidity. The finish is long with lingering bittersweet coffee. Overall: As a fan of coffee beers, this one rocks.

(12oz bottle, courtesy of blutt59)  Pours a dark brown body with a medium tan head.  Aroma of pine, coffee grounds, light citrus, and lactose.  Flavor of coffee, roasted malt, caramel, lactose, and chocolate.

Draft @ Shorts:  Pours a pitch black...nose is massive amounts of rich, fresh coffee.....................and not much else.  There are a few underlying notes of what may be chocolate malt apparent but this is all coffee.  Medium-full bodied....flavor pretty much follows the lead of the nose, massive amounts of coffee with some vanilla bean to note.  Top notch coffee-based stout.

Bottle:  The aroma is loaded with roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and just a hint of vanilla.  It pours a dark brown, virtually black, with a large brown head that fades within half a minute or so...some better retention and lacing from being a 5 in appearance.  The flavor is exactly what you get in the aroma.  It starts with lots of dark chocolate.  The finish has lots of roasted coffee and a hint of vanilla.  Medium-full bodied with somewhat lively carbonation for a stout.

Pours dark brown. Nice creamy head. Aromas of coffee, roasted malts, and chocolate. Full bodied and creamy. Smooth, silky feel to it. Hops, cream, coffee, and chocolate. Long roasty lingering finsh with head still sitting at the bottom of glass.
Bottle from punkrkr27..pours black with a mocha head..aroma slightly sweet with black coffee...Flavor is dark malts, chocolate and coffee..thin body with lots of carbonation..pretty tasty

12oz bottle from Holiday Market. Pours almost black with thick dark tan head which is still bubbling 15 minutes after pouring. Aromas of roasted coffee, chocolate, and some roasted malts. Flavors of dry roasted malts, some chocolate, and loads of coffee. Finishes dry with bitter coffee. Lively carbonation. Solid coffee stout.
bottle, via trade with mibirder, black coffee pour with strong bitter coffee aroma, flavor is inky black espresso and burnt toast, nice lasting finish

12oz bottle. Poured a dark black color with a larger sized tan head. Aromas of coffee, roasty, light chocolate, some cream, and light smoke. Nice coffee in the aroma. Tastes of coffee, cream, chocolate, and roasty. I love coffee beers and this one did not disappoint me.

12oz bottle shared by bring on BA - thanks, Barry!  While some of the Shorts beers did not impress, this one was awesome and then some.  Pours black like coffee with a large tan head and very nice lacing.  A crapload of fresh coffee jumps out at you in the aroma.  More potent and good-smelling than most coffee beers.  Some roasted malt and chocolate are also present.  Flavor is amazing - freshly brewed, rich mocha with cream.  The coffee flavor blends seamlessly with the rest of the beer, and the cream really starts to make its presence known as the beer sits for awhile.  Amazingly smooth and creamy on the palate with medium-full body and almost none of the harsh bitterness that other coffee beers can have.  I wouldnt mind drinking one of these every morning.  Unfortunately my job has an annoying "no alcohol at work" policy.  Lame.

Another Shorts beer courtesy of hoppymeal.

Pours pitch black out of the bottle, completely opaque with a big thick mocha head that refuses to die and sticks to glass stubbornly on the way down.

As a coffee beer lover, I might be a bit biased, but this thing smells fantastic.  Freshly ground coffee, sweet cream, dark roasted malts - just spot on for the style and completely fills the nose.

The taste isnt quite as heavenly as the nose, but its close.  The spent coffee grounds are still in full force along with the  big lactose sweetness.  Tastes like an iced latte.  The only complaint I have in the taste is its a tad too bitter but thats nitpicking.

The mouthfeel is probably what keeps this one from the pantheon of coffee beers in my mind.  Its just too carbonated for a stout in my opinion.

As a coffee beer lover, this one certainly hits the spot and if they ramped the carbonation down a little, this would be a world class beer.  As it stands, its just plain great!

Pours black with a light brown head. The aroma is strong coffee with some light smoke. The flavor is strong coffee with some cream, about what you expect after reading the label. Good bitterness and some roasted malt and chocolate. Medium-thick, semi-creamy mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

( 12oz bottle thanks to blutt59) Pours black with nice creamy tan head. Nose of coffee, cream, and raw wet coffee grounds. Taste of coffee, cream, and a very creamy finish. This tastes really sweet and was an awesome unique beer.

Growler.  Poured a deep reddish brown with a fluffy light brown head.  Nose is coffee, roasted malt, and some chocolate.  Body was slightly thin with an oily mouth feel.  Flavor starts with somewhat strong coffee which leads into sweet roasted malts with light chocolate and caramel notes.  Finishes roasted.
Thanks to KlevelandRocks for this one!  Viscous black pour.  Thick brown head that quickly fades.  No lace.  Aroma is in your face coffee.   Roasted coffee beans, chocolate, and a dry creamy finish.

bottle thanks to blutt59.  black with an epsresso head.  wow, thats not anything but coffee, roasted and ground beans pretty much.  nice on the palate with a big kick in the face of coffee and that about sums it up.

Bottle thanks to blutt59. Pours with a large tan head over a black body. Lots of coffee. Starbucks. Fresh Roast. Slight earthy hop notes. Taste is just fully coffee with light sweetener. Ridiculous amount of coffee.  Creamy carbonation.

A winner, and definitely my favorite so far from this brewery.  Not very sessionable, however.  


rerate.  much much more sugary and sweet than i remember, and the coffee presense has faded.  Bottle from the same six pack consumed three months after original bottle.  Couldnt finish the bottle.  way too sugary.

Bottle thanks to Toby Pours out a black topped with a small tan head. Aroma is of rich dark malts, coffee, and some chocolate. Taste much as the aroma plenty of coffee, bitter dark chocolate, and a little sweet pit fruit.

this gets a big meh from me. the coffee is more like burnt, used coffee grounds than fresh brewed coffee. big coffee grounds nose, bit of chocolate. about the same on the front, but the back end leaves you with used coffee grounds again.

Thanks to hoppymeal for this growler.  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Nose is coffee, roast, earth, and lactose.  Flavor is deep and dark: roasted, earthy coffee with hints of milk and cream. On tap. Poured black with a coffee brown head. Aroma was full of espresso coffee notes with a nice roasted malt undertone. Flavor was amazingly refreshing with a nice coffee flavor and undertones of roasted malts and a slight chocolate note.

Growler pours blackness with full frothy light mocha head. The aroma is very coffee like with a modest level of burnt malts around the edges. The taste has a smooth and almost velvety mouth feel. Oh man.  Black pour with mud colored head that leaves a rim around the glass.  Big coffee aroma with a bit of vanilla cream.  Some roasty chocolate goodness.  Flavor is excellent for a coffee stout. growler, Tampa gathering.
pours black, mocha head.
